questions.question: A family died in a closed room that was full of smoke from a wood fire. Which of the following findings is likely to be seen on the body?
questions.explanation: room full of smoke from a wood fire, which likely caused carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning. Cherry-red post-mortem staining is a hallmark sign of carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning. Postmortem Staining in Poisoning Cases Postmortem staining (Livor mortis) is the skin discoloration after death due to blood settling in dependent areas. The color of the staining can indicate certain types of poisoning: Poison Postmortem Staining Characteristics Opium (Option C ruled out) Purple or blackish staining Carbon monoxide (Option A) Cherry red discoloration (COHb > 30%) Hydrogen sulfide Greenish discoloration in tissues Datura Asphyxial signs (no specific color) Organochlorine/Kerosene Asphyxial signs (no specific color) Phosphates, aniline, and nitrites (Option D ruled out) Brown-colored pigmentation Carbon Monoxide Physical Appearance Odourless, colorless, non-irritating gas, lighter than air Sources of Poisoning Incomplete combustion of almost of fuel (wood, charcoal, gas, kerosene) Automobile exhaust Fires: A common cause of accidental CO poisoning resulting in mass deaths - large building (hotel, theatre, block of flats, etc.) in flames Paint remover (especially methylene chloride) Tobacco smoke Normal CO level in plasma 1 to 5 % 7 to 8 % in smokers Mode of Action 230 to 270 times greater affinity for hemoglobin than oxygen Leftward shift of the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve Reduced arterial oxygen content Inactivating mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase - cellular respiration is interfered CO-induced brain injuries are common in basal ganglia, cerebral white matter, hippocampus, and cerebellum. Clinical Features Depends on the concentration of CO in the blood CO exposure during pregnancy is teratogenic Diagnosis Carboxyhemoglobin level (COHb) in blood Arterial blood gases Treatment Oxygen (100%) through a tight-fitting mask or endotracheal tube, until COHb falls to 15 to 20% Hyperbaric oxygen: Inhalation of oxygen at a pressure greater than 1 atmosphere absolute Autopsy Findings Cherry red (pink) color of skin, inner aspects of lips, nail beds, tongue, palms and soles Cutaneous bullae (skin blisters) in the calves, buttocks, wrists, and knees Cherry pink color of blood and tissues Firmer white matter of the brain Necrosis and cavitation of basal ganglia Cyanosis (Option B) is not appreciated in CO poisoning. Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 539, 564, 587, 590, 602.

questions.question: A person died suddenly whose family is abroad. His viscera was preserved during autopsy. Which of the following can be detected in his visceral organs even on non-consumption before his death?
questions.explanation: detected in the viscera due to the fermentation of body fluids and tissues. This post-mortem production of alcohol can make its detection possible even if the person did not consume alcohol before death. Morphine (Options A), Aconite (Option B), and Arsenic (Option C) can only be detected if they were consumed by the person Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8840458

questions.question: During autopsy of fetal death case, What is the order of examination to differentiate between live birth and stillbirth?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Head > Thorax > Abdomen Explanation: During the autopsy of a fetal death case, the order of internal examination is critical for determining whether the fetus was stillborn or live-born . The standard and most logical approach is: Head → Thorax → Abdomen This sequence helps preserve important evidence: Head (first) : Intracranial haemorrhages or maceration changes may help estimate time of death. If the head is opened later, it may be distorted by loss of cerebrospinal fluid and pressure changes during thoracic/abdominal dissection. Thorax (second) : Hydrostatic test (lung float test) is crucial for determining live birth vs stillbirth . This test must be done before cutting major vessels to avoid artificial inflation of lungs. Abdomen (last) : Examined after thoracic cavity, especially to avoid displacement of gas or fluids that can affect findings (e.g. bowel gas mimicking respiration). Step Purpose Head Check for intracranial injuries, maceration, skull ossification Thorax Vital for hydrostatic lung test (float/sink test) Abdomen Check for organ development, meconium, and anomalies Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC1860427/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6379179/

questions.question: Blood during autopsy is preserved in?
questions.explanation: for blood is sodium fluoride. Various methods of preserving viscera: Saturated salt solution Formalin fixation Freezing Alcohol preservation Formaldehyde solution Formalin-alcohol solution Frozen section Liquid nitrogen Specimens for Analysis Specimen Importance Blood Primary specimen; collect from femoral, iliac, or axillary veins to avoid contamination. Preservative: Lithium heparin or EDTA tube, Sodium fluoride/oxalate (Option A) , if alcohol is suspected Urine Useful for detecting parent compounds and metabolites of poisons. Preservative: No preservative, sodium fluoride is added, if alcohol is Suspected Gastric Contents Helps identify ingested poisons and their concentrations through vomitus and stomach contents analysis. Preservative: Saturated salt solution if there is no chance of acid poison. (Option B) Rectified spirit if poisoned by acid (Option C) . Liver Analyzes metabolism and concentration of drugs; critical when blood/urine concentrations are low. Bile can detect specific substances like chlorpromazine and morphine. Preservative: Saturated salt solution if there is no chance of acid poison. Rectified spirit if poisoned by acid. Hair and Nails Detects heavy metal poisoning; metals accumulate in keratin. Neutron activation analysis identifies specific metals and exposure patterns. Scene Residues Provides clues about the poison through materials found at the scene, such as tablets or empty containers. Formalin (Option C) is commonly used for general tissue preservation and fixation in anatomical pathology, but it is not specifically preferred for toxicology autopsy. It may affect the results of toxicological analyses. Reference: Goutam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 3rd edition, page 114.

questions.question: During a police investigation, some bones are uncovered from the crime scene. Which of the following tests would aid in differentiating between human and canine bones, during the forensic analysis?
questions.explanation: the precipitin test. Precipitin tests can be done by extracting species-specific protein from bone into a solution and testing it against specific antisera of humans. The techniques such as electrophoresis or gel diffusion can now identify human tissue. Confirmatory Tests for Blood Stains in Forensic Medicine Confirmatory tests are critical for identifying blood presence and origin in forensic investigations. Methods include chemical, immunological, and mass spectrometry techniques for reliable results. Chemical Confirmatory Tests Test Description Takayama Test Detects hemoglobin by forming red, feathery crystals of pyridine ferroprotoporphyrin. Teichmann Test (Option D ruled out) Converts hemoglobin to hemin, creating brownish-yellow rhomboid crystals, confirming blood presence. Immunological Tests Test Description Precipitin Test (Option A) Identifies species origin through antibody-antigen reactions, using antisera specific to human blood. HemaTrace Test Uses monoclonal antibodies to detect human hemoglobin, showing a visible pink band for confirmation. Mass Spectrometry Techniques Thread Spray Mass Spectrometry : Analyzes whole blood directly on textiles, differentiating species based on lipid composition and hemoglobin chains. It offers high sensitivity and specificity. Acid-phosphatase (Option B) This test can be used to detect seminal fluid. LDH (Option C) cannot be used for species differentiation.

questions.question: The graph depicting the post-mortem cooling process is typically expected to have what shape?
questions.explanation: gradually at first, reaches a midpoint, and then cools more rapidly. Incorrect Options: Option A - Hyperbolic: A hyperbolic curve would suggest rapid initial cooling followed by a slower decline, which is not characteristic of post-mortem cooling. Option C - Linear: This option implies a constant rate of cooling over time. Again, the linear cooling pattern doesn't accurately represent the post-mortem cooling process, which is more complex. Option D - Parabolic: A parabolic curve would imply a constant rate of cooling, which doesn't align with the observed pattern of post-mortem cooling. Reference: .

questions.question: What is the specific name of the test performed by the doctor during the autopsy where they tied the bronchus and submerged the lung in water to determine if it floats or sinks?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Hydrostatic test Explanation: The test described, where the bronchus is tied and the lung is immersed in water to check whether it floats or sinks, is known as the Hydrostatic test. Hydrostatic test/ Raygat's test/ Breslau's 1 life test/ Lung floatation test If the baby had respired, the alveoli would be expanded/ dilated. Thus, as the lungs are expanded, alveoli are dilated & the specific gravity decreases. Alveoli are dilated d/t presence of residual air. When lungs are expanded, specific gravity becomes <1. Thus, they float when they are placed in the water This test is performed to assess the buoyancy of the lung, as the presence of air within the lung tissue causes it to float in water. It is used as a supportive indication of drowning, as drowning often leads to the aspiration of water into the lungs, resulting in increased lung buoyancy. Incorrect Options: Gettler's test (Option A): It is based on the chloride concentration in the blood samples of heart chambers. Normally, chloride concentration in both right side chambers & left side chambers should be equal Ploucquet's test (Option B): Plouquet's test is a test used to detect ratio between Weight of the lung to the Weight of the baby. Diatom's test (Option D): Diatom's test is a forensic examination that involves analyzing the presence of diatoms, in various tissues and , fluids to determine if a person was submerged in water. Reference: Hydrostatic test
